PROGUANIL HYDROCHLORIDE

  • Pregnancy

Indications and doses

Prophylaxis of malaria,

By mouth

  • For adults
    200 mg once daily, dose to be started 1 week before entering endemic area and continued for 4 weeks after leaving.
  • For children up to 11 weeks (body-weight up to 6 kg)
    25 mg once daily, dose to be started 1 week before entering endemic area and continued for 4 weeks after leaving.
  • For children 3–11 months (body-weight 6–9 kg)
    50 mg once daily, dose to be started 1 week before entering endemic area and continued for 4 weeks after leaving.
  • For children 1–3 years (body-weight 10–16 kg)
    75 mg once daily, dose to be started 1 week before entering endemic area and continued for 4 weeks after leaving.
  • For children 4–7 years (body-weight 16–25 kg)
    100 mg once daily, dose to be started 1 week before entering endemic area and continued for 4 weeks after leaving.
  • For children 8–12 years (body-weight 25–45 kg)
    150 mg once daily, dose to be started 1 week before entering endemic area and continued for 4 weeks after leaving.
  • For children 13–17 years (body-weight 46 kg and above)
    200 mg once daily, dose to be started 1 week before entering endemic area and continued for 4 weeks after leaving.

Advice when patient is pregnant

Benefit of prophylaxis in malaria outweighs risk.

Adequate folate supplements should be given to mother.

Advice regarding renal impairment

In children

Use half normal dose if estimated glomerular filtration rate 20–60 mL/minute/1.73m2.

Use one-quarter normal dose on alternate days if estimated glomerular filtration rate 10–20 mL/minute/1.73m2.

Use one-quarter normal dose once weekly if estimated glomerular filtration rate less than 10 mL/minute/1.73m2.

Increased risk of haematological toxicity.

In adults

100 mg once daily if eGFR 20–60 mL/minute/1.73m2.

50 mg on alternate days if eGFR 10–20 mL/minute/1.73m2.

50 mg once weekly if eGFR less than 10 mL/minute/1.73m2.

Increased risk of haematological toxicity.

Known side effects

General side effects

commonOrVeryCommon: Constipation, diarrhoea, mild gastric intolerance,

veryRare: Cholestasis, hair loss, skin reactions, vasculitis,

notKnown: Mouth ulcers, stomatitis,

Directions for administration

Tablet may be crushed and mixed with food such as milk, jam, or honey just before administration.

Advice for patients and carers

Warn travellers about importance of avoiding mosquito bites, importance of taking prophylaxis regularly, and importance of immediate visit to doctor if ill within 1 year and especially within 3 months of return.

National funding/access decisions

Unlicensed use

Proguanil doses in BNF Publications may differ from those in product literature.

Exceptions to legal category

Can be sold to the public provided it is licensed and labelled for the prophylaxis of malaria.

Prepared medicinal forms of PROGUANIL HYDROCHLORIDE

There can be variation in the licensing of different medicines containing the same drug.

Forms available from special-order manufacturers include: oral solution, oral suspension,
Tablet
